title: What is your opinion on LGBT Christians? - Quora

response.answer_text: I respect them too much to have an opinion about them. These are often people who manage to hold on to God despite the best efforts of a society who loves to scapegoat (i.e. assign unbearable guilt and exact an unpayable price). The first time I remember consciously being confronted with the question of gay and lesbian believers was when I saw the film Trembling Before G-d (2001). The film is made from a Jewish perspective, but I was left with a strong impression of a people suffering for their faith and “striving with God”. This is a curious aspect of Israel’s identity — that they were not being defined by their struggles with other gods or other nations, but had to work out their own salvation with “fear and trembling”. And as a Christian, I could not help asking myself how Jesus might have responded. There are multiple examples where he engaged with the marginalised and spoke on their behalf — not despite his faith, but because of it. At each encounter, he would recognise and affirm the faith of these untouchables. Then he would turn around and rebuke the community who had cornered them. Finally, Jesus himself was scapegoated for disturbing the peace. We can guess whose peace was disturbed. It certainly wasn’t any of the ordinary people whose honour and dignity he had restored before God (the word “forgiven” doesn’t quite capture this implication in our litigious society). I am acutely aware of the fact that people, my own faith community very much included, have been trying (and mostly failing) to work this out culturally and theologically. Change is slow in coming. In the meantime, the more I read and engage with this little Israel among us, I find there is no place left to hide God’s grace, which has so overwhelmed my own failings that all I have left to express is love and compassion. Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted.Blessed are the meek, for they will inherit the earth.Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be filled.Blessed are the merciful, for they will receive mercy.Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God.Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God.Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness’ sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.Blessed are you when people revile you and persecute you and utter all kinds of evil against you on my account. — Jesus (Matthew 5)

I lived as a conservative Christian for over 30 years. I have read the entire Bible in: New International Version, New King James Version, Holman Christian Standard Bible, and New Living Translation. I have also studied the Bible in a few other versions, I just haven’t read the whole thing in any other versions. I have been a member of several different churches and at least attended several different types of Christian churches I feel very confident that I know and understand what the Bible has to say about homosexuality. The Bible does have kind of a LOT to say about homosexuality. There’s at least one verse about cross dressing… probably a few, but not many. I sincerely don’t recall a single verse on transsexual identification, which is a different issue. The verse I am aware of is in the Old Testament, and I feel certain any others would be too. According to the Bible and mainstream Christianity, Jesus is the fulfillment of the law, and there are a lot of other things that mainstream Christianity believes that effects. Based on my previous sincere beliefs (which resulted from a combination of intensive personal study and receiving broad based Christian teaching): Practicing homosexuality will result in going to hell (it’s not about sexual orientation, it’s about giving in to temptation to sin… it is engaging in homosexual acts that is sinful, not having homosexual desires). A small minority of Christians/churches do sincerely believe that practicing homosexuality can be Biblically justified, and that it is possible for Christians to be practicing homosexuals and go to heaven. If my beliefs were accurate, they would be unable to justify that position to God. They might be able to convince people, but God would NOT be persuaded. People can believe what they want to, but they would not have a chance in hell of convincing God on judgment day. The GOOD NEWS, from my perspective, is that GOD doesn’t EXIST. As long as there is NO GOD, it really makes ZERO difference what they believe about it. I honestly believe it’s perfectly safe for LGBTQ people to believe whatever they want to. When I transitioned, I couldn’t “just change my beliefs based on what LGBTQ friendly people and churches believed”. My beliefs were MY OWN BELIEFS… I couldn’t just change them to accommodate my preference. If your beliefs are based on what someone else tells you, you might be able to be convinced. If you ACTUALLY have YOUR OWN BELIEFS, it’s not real easy change them. It’s a lot easier to change your beliefs when they are based on what someone else tells you. I really had to examine my beliefs and reach a sincere resolution that I had peace about. I DID that, and I have peace about what I believe again now. I’m not trying to convert anyone, I really don’t believe what people believe matters… as long as they are not using their beliefs to justify hurting other people (unfortunately, many religious people ARE guilty of that (including Christians, it’s not “just a Muslim problem”).

I have no particular opinion on them. God can and will give salvation to anyone of any kind. There is no requirement aside from consenting. Some like to say you can’t be homosexual, bisexual, or whatever and be christians, but that’s BS. That is saying that there is sins that are more powerful than what Jesus did, which is pretty much blasphemy. People forget that God changes people. Their desires can change. The Gospel is powerful. Change isn’t instant. I do not condemn LGBT christians. People struggle with all sorts of things.

Hi. LGBT Christian here. Didn’t realize it for most of my life (the LGBT part). It’s a fascinating…I’m going to use the word bridge. A lot of the LGBT community is non-Christian (for a myriad of reasons primarily Christians haven’t given them good reasons to be Christians) and a lot of Christians haven’t interacted with LGBT people. So I often get to be an insightful window for both groups (I have actually been able to chat quite freely about my faith with LGBT people and my gender identity/sexuality with Christians including faith leaders). I am honestly sad I don’t know more, but I am fully aware of why. There’s a lot of people in the LGBT community who have been hurt by Christians. There is a facebook group I’m a part of that is for LGBT Christians and the stories in there sometimes just break my heart. I think that LGBT Christians have an interesting perspective on both. I could describe my transition and my faith being intertwined and I have heard other LGBT Christians speak about their experiences as an LGBT person giving them some unique insights into their faith. The Church is really missing out on these perspectives if they’re going to continue pushing them away. I’m very grateful my current church has been the exact opposite of that.

If they truly adhere to Christianity, and not some altered offshoot of it, they should be attempting to cease homosexual behavior. If they are legitimately trying to do this, yet are failing and fall back into it at times, I say welcome to the club. They are exactly like all Christians who are tying to limit sin yet falter. They should ask for forgiveness and attempt to do better next time. I fully accept these people as Christian and would be happy to try to help them in their walks and have them help me in mine. If, on the other hand, they have totally rejected clear Biblical teachings on homosexual behavior, or at minimum ignore those sections and therefore willfully and continously participate in it without any attempt to remove it from their lives because they don't believe it's a sin, then I wouldn't call them Christians. They could still be great people who adhere to some or many of the values the Bible promotes, but they have clearly given up on the Bible as the word of God and are trying to make it say something it doesn't through some pretty outlandish mental gymnastics. To me, Christians don't willfully and consistently do that. It's one thing to sin, know you are sinning, and legitimately attempt to stop sinning but fail. It's another to outright reject the clear cut teachings of the very book the religion is based on and just start measuring sin by whatever metric you see fit. Christians can and will do the former according to the Bible, but I've never quite understood how or why people would even want to do the latter and still refer to themselves as Christian. In short, my opinion on the Christianity of LGBT people or any other people has nothing to do with their sins. It has to do with whether or not their underlying worldview regarding those sins (and how they should respond to them) completely rejects obvious Biblical teachings.

Well I think it appropriate we turn to the Bible for a clear indication on whether you can be a Christian and LGBT. In Romans it talks clearly about sexual desires. “Therefore God gave them over in the sinful desires of their hearts to sexual impurity for the degrading of their bodies with one another” (Romans 1:24). It then goes on to speak about men being with other men. “Because of this, God gave them over to shameful lusts. Even their women exchanged natural sexual relations for unnatural ones. In the same way the men also abandoned natural relations with women and were inflamed with lust for one another. Men committed shameful acts with other men, and received in themselves the due penalty for their error.” (Romans 1:26–27) Corinthians also clearly talks about homosexuals, specifically directed towards those who are in the church. “Or do you not know that wrongdoers will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived: Neither the sexually immoral nor idolaters nor adulterers nor men who have sex with men nor thieves nor the greedy nor drunkards nor slanderers nor swindlers will inherit the kingdom of God.” (1 Corinthians 5:9–10). And again further in the passage (12, 13, 14). There are also other verses which I have not mentioned, that also talk about homosexuality. I think the evidence is clear.

Well, being that I could be an LBGT Christian (I’m questioning my sexuality), and having interacted with many LBGT Christians, I’d like to say that we are all Christians. Some of us feel abandoned by the congregation we grew up in. Some of us leave the faith. Some of us stay. Some of us decide to remain celibate for the rest of our lives. Some of us decide to get married. I think it’s a very closed-minded statement to say the LGBT Christians (and even their allies) are not Christian. Just because some of us may have a different interpretation on the scripture doesn’t mean that it’s automatically wrong. My entire denomination (I’m a Protestant) was formed because people had a different interpretation on the scripture. Many of us know why our fellow Christians think homosexuality is wrong, and we know why we agree, disagree, or just don’t know what to think about that statement. Either way, we are all Christians, just maybe not cisgender or straight. Hope you have a good day! :)
